Played this a few years ago and still one of my favourites. The graphics are so stunning that I found myself staring at my screen in awe, forgetting to blink and turning into a real-life version of the "Pikachu meme" face. Sorry, Mom, I can't come to dinner—my civilization just entered the Industrial Age

And then there are the wonders. Have you ever built the Great Library, only to realize you don't have enough money left to buy books? Well, welcome to my civilization! It's a land of knowledge without the actual knowledge. But hey, at least my people can brag about having a monument dedicated to their collective cluelessness.

Oh, and don't even get me started on the endless wars! Gandhi was supposed to be the peaceful guy, but I think he has a hidden button on his desk that says, "Launch the Nukes!" Seriously, every time I try to extend an olive branch, he's out there plotting my demise, and it's like, "Dude, chill! I just wanted to trade some spices."

But you know what? Despite all the chaos and the occasional questionable AI decisions, Civilization VI is a masterpiece. It's like a circus for history nerds, where you can build your own utopia or accidentally create a dystopian society that will haunt your dreams. It's educational, addictive, and best of all, it helps you procrastinate on your real-life responsibilities like a true champ.

So, if you're ready to question your productivity, bid farewell to sleep, and go on a journey where you'll be haunted by your decisions for days, then this is the game for you. 133428748.review:
I absolutely loved Civ 5 and it is one of my favorite games of all time, so I immediately purchased this game back in 2016 with very high hopes it would blow me away and be the next game I sunk 1000+ hours into playing.  Unfortunately, I couldn't quite even get to the 100 hour mark with this game in the 6+ years I've owned it and found myself going back to Civ 5 even to this day.

The game improves a lot in the features from Civ 5, allowing more ways run your civilization with the unit improvements such as allowing attachment of civilian unites to military ones to protect them as well as allowing districts so that a city that was started surrounded by land could still access the ocean if it was at least a few tiles away.  But even with all of these improvements, I couldn't get over a lot of the aesthetic choices they went with this game.  The cartoony and exaggerated expressions from the Civ leaders and units didn't really click with me and kind of made the experience feel more cheap as compared to the more realistic and compelling aesthetic that Civ 5 had.  I also did not like the change of workers expiring after improving a certain amount of tiles whereas 5 kept your workers to continually improve.

The agenda system also does dampen the experience a little for me as well as I often found leaders despising me just because I wouldn't fit what they prefer, such as lacking in culture.  I'm sure others would find this setting interesting as it adds another dynamic in relations, but I found it very annoying as it didn't make a lot of sense to ruin relations just because my empire wasn't progressing in a way that the AI thought suitable.

It may be a fit unfair with how much I do compare this game to Civ 5, but it is hard not to given this was the next step taken in the series.  Given how I hold Civ 5 in such high regard and how much of a let down this game was in comparison, I honestly cannot recommend it to others.  If you did not like Civ 5, this game might be a good change of pace to get into.  But if you are similar to me and love Civ 5, I would recommend awaiting to see if Civ 7 will be the next step that takes the series to a higher level, as Civ 6 failed to do so in my opinion.

I've recently been playing Civilization 6. As with Factorio, it's a game I've sunk a lot of hours into but have mixed feelings about. Equally addictive. I'm probably highly susceptible to Civ as it's basically a board game on a scale that would be impossible to fit on a table. Scythe or Root scaled up to the max!

You can boot Civ up, then spend 7 hours nursing a nation from the stone age to launching nuclear weapons at your neighbours. Compelling stuff. In that time, you'll skip lunch without realising you feel hungry. The odd thing is, I'm not sure it's that fun in the moment. It's all about what the future might hold, and the promise of potential rewards. The interlocking systems are so deep that there's a lot to consider to get the optimal outcome. That keeps you going on for just one more turn.

Once you actually defeat your neighbours and take their cities, what was previously all consuming is no longer important. If anything, it's more effort as you now need to micromanage even more things. With more of the map revealed there is less mystery and wonder, and the modern era turns into a slog to complete whatever victory condition you're aiming for.

I think I'm going to stop now after only losing 50 hours of my life. That's a small price to pay compared to most. I'll still occasionally watch lets plays on YouTube though. I've gotten into PotatoMcWhiskey's video series, which I've found to be a relaxing low effort way to chill without getting hooked on the actual game. That's enough for me.

So, should you play it? Maybe. It might be worth a try, but be very careful. It could take a lot of time from you!

I bought this game when it first came out, played awhile, and then uninstalled it. I tried it again now, years later, to see if my opinion has changed (or perhaps updates had improved it) but no dice.

This game has made the misguided DLC features that were added to Civ 5 as core game elements. I know what the developers were trying to do and why but they went about it the wrong way. A Civ game should be about the player making large strategic decisions, and while one could decide to micromanage a little, mostly by allocation of civilians at cities, it was generally easy to ignore most of that and focus your attention on your borders and military forces, making appropriate diplomatic and militaristic decisions to keep your people happy.

Civ 6 takes thing the opposite direction. It forces the player to spend an inordinate amount of time micromanaging their empire for very little benefit. The developers didn't need to hyper-focus on trade, religion, and tourism; these elements were already represented in much simpler and abstract way. Now I am arranging artwork in museums, constantly telling traders which cities to go to, and dealing with a constant influx of missionaries that flood over the borders of my empire.

Civ needed new, bold ideas to describe different aspects of a culture and then gamify them, not a bunch of new specialty units and micro-games for a player to juggle and eat up their time.

I do like some of the new aspects of city building. It was a clever way to add more customization. However, the overall general happiness system is removed and replaced with a more complicated amenities and housing system that doesn't really add anything to the game - just another tedious things to manage. I already have to worry about feeding cities to grow their population - now I have to worry about making them homes to? Will a future update or game add a plumber unit I need to order about to unclog drains?

On the plus side, they got Sean Bean to narrate. Great choice.

Expansive Civilization Building: From constructing cities and managing resources to leading scientific advancements and forming diplomatic relations, Civilization® VI offers a broad spectrum of gameplay mechanics that cater to various playstyles.

TL;DR The game is addicting but all of the win conditions feel empty and generally uninteresting to progress. They also almost never intersect in and interesting or rewarding making game progression unrewarding. 
Unrewarding gameplay tied with an obnoxious amount of micro-managing makes the game often feel like a chore after the first 50 or so turns. + DLC and CIV 7 announced

Considering this is the 6th game in the franchise you would expect some finely polished gameplay but most of what the game shows you is crap. The game over complicates so many basic aspects by just adding more but the majority of content is so inconsequential to the outcome of your games. After a while you'll start learning what few government policies that are actually worth looking at and the few important strategic resources worth hoarding.

The game has 4 (technically 5) different Victory conditions and honestly none is particularly well designed. Religion is so OP, brain-dead and fast that i easily got my first win with it despite not knowing what I was doing. Culture is slow and exceptionally tedious forcing you to micro-manage a bunch of units late game, I assume because the devs thought more APM = more Depth. Both of these conditions have the same problem where they don't have any progression at all past round 50. Once your Religion is established and apostles unlocked circa round 50 religious gameplay remains the same for the next 300-500 turns.

Science is technically the same as Religion and Culture where the strategy is just build as many fully maxed out building X while supplementing with the X government but it ends up 100x more enjoyable because it doesn't force you to brainlessly micro-manage 15 different units. Letting you play with all the things on the tech tree also helps Science games not feel like a drag. Certainly better than Culture and Religion but not great.

Domination is by far the most interesting wincon, as its the only one that actually has any real substantial progression. Which is a shame because the game does everything in its power to make a domination victory the most difficult and tedious experience possible. The game rewards slow deliberate capture of territory over 100s of turns and makes extended combat a net negative for everyone involved. This sounds like a good idea that lets everyone stay in the game while letting an aggressive player slowly get rewarded but in reality 99% of the time it just leads to one nation who got a lucky spawn away from any aggression getting the win because they were allowed to focus 100% on their goal (Whilst you and the guy playing Rome besieging you end the game 1st and 2nd on domination lead while last in everything else.)

Honestly while the games problems aren't easy to ignore I still enjoy it quite a bit. The big thing stopping my recommendation is the mountain of DLC required to get the 'true experience'. The external launcher and looming knowledge that development is finished to focus on CIV 7 is just the nail in the coffin.

Thumbs down to this game for several reasons. The gist of it, just not as good as Civ 5. There will be a continuous theme that I will try to lay out as I write this: The game either lacks any sense or it does not have any logical sense. Do not get me wrong. The game is fun. I was entertained and hooked for some amount of time but the decisions made in this game are glaring when compared to civ 5. It is sad to see a decline from such a great game.

-DLC are terrible, do not add much value and overly priced. Not really worth your time.

-The whole aesthetics of the game is pretty fortnite-like to me. Civ 5 was also a bit cartoon-ish but it felt way more serious and impactful, you were an actual leader of the world trying to achieve your goals. Civ 6 feels like a circus, everything seems as it is a joke, very cartoon like and magical. Obviously the game is very beautiful and looks superb, the tone is completely off and Firaxis has deviated way too much to please who? After seeing a few interviews, it seems they are trying to get a more whimsical crowd to play the game. Civ 5 is better.

-Graphics in this game are amazing.

-Early game civilisations > Late game civilisations. I do not know if this is accurate but from what I have seen, being able to snowball early can mean you become unbeatable. Not really balanced. I enjoy this aspect of the game very much but the bonuses each civilisation has are too strong.

-Combat is sincerely unbalanced and very punishing if you do not know the meta. There are so many bloody bonuses from religion, governors, unique traits, etc. I have watched people get +20 combat bonus or more on their units and it seems insane. Forget deity, in multiplayer you can get trashed by a military that is behind scientifically very easily. You have to get these bonuses and know how to get them or you will get trashed in multiplayer. The rock-paper-scissor still works very well in this entry but units are also quite forgettable. Nothing beats England's long bowmen from civ 5 or ship of the line. Combat feels very smooth and easy to understand, even though RNG can be a problem.

-Gameplay is pretty trash. I cannot think of a single mechanic that Civ 6 has improved to Civ 5. I think the only mechanic that was good was spies.

    *Religion is boring and the game play is not entertaining. I do not know anyone who really tries to win through religion. It is awfully tedious. I am the most ignorant about this aspect.

    *You have to place districts and wonders on tiles which restricts your territory and placing these in a certain formation grants you from minor bonuses to massive ones. Why? Because the game developers said so. My gripe is wonders and districts take an entire tile, removing bonuses the land was giving you and giving you an adjacency bonuses if it is next to certain other districts, improvements, resources and wonders. Most of these bonuses in the game make no logical sense, for some civilisations the bonuses can be massive, it restricts your freedom on how you want to build your cities (you can play however you like but the repercussions are huge if you do not optimise your cities) and it causes you to micromanage your cities twice as much as you would in Civ 5. It causes games to prolong way too much, adding several hours to your sessions. Once you get to end game, it is so tedious to continue playing. So many little details which has to be taken into account and no way to automate. I wish I could hire governors to automate cities for me because I really do not want to have to give orders every single turn for mundane stuff. Thankfully there is Shift+Enter to skip all orders and end turn. Age of Wonders has a fantastic mechanic which is, idle cities produce merchandise automatically which gives you bonus gold depending on your production. God, such a simple mechanic and Firaxis cannot even fathom a solution to this. Civ 5 is better just because none of these bonuses exist and wonders are placed automatically in one of your tiles, giving a nice subtle aesthetic look to your cities.

    *I miss being able to automate my workers. Nope, that does not exist here. Micromanage is once again very tedious. I personally sell or kill all my workers after a certain era because it starts becoming more annoying than beneficial. My personal view is they should just remove workers from the game and replace it with a different mechanic. Also workers having 3 charges then disappear is probably the worst mechanic in this game. I would understand if my worker was building the pyramids it would probably die, but a farm? My worker makes 3 farms and it dies? What is the logic behind it? 
At least make workers not have charges when you reach a certain era or research workers right or something. Probably has to do with balance. Civ 5 is better in every way.

    *Eureka and inspirations are absolute garbage. They force you into playing one way, pigeon hole you into a meta to maximise your research and culture which are extremely important in Civ 6. Basically, you have a checklist of things to do. Not doing this checklist punishes you severely. Do not have iron around? You get punished. Do not want to build spearman and use it to kill a unit? You get punished. No hills to build mines? You get punished. What is the punishment? Research and culture taking more turns to complete. So I decided to leave the familiar waters of Civ4 to try out its latest successor. What I encountered was downright uncivilized: It's a cartoon mobile game.

Hey player, get ready to COOPERATE with your FRIENDLY NEIGHBORS to PROMOTE PEACE and PROGRESS among the people of THE WORLD, so we can SAVE THE PLANET. There's nothing stopping the player from ignoring this tone and playing in the usual competitive, aggressive and imperialist way, but it seems the writers saw a great need to tell you DO NOT ACTUALLY DO THIS COOL THING IT IS IMMORAL AND BAD. There are few of the highly controversial leaders left in the game - Stalin and Mao are gone, for example - and instead we now have a less eurocentric and more feminine cast of leaders. Sure, it's just a game, but you can see which way the wind is blowing.

Speaking of the leaders, they have faces. Whoever designed and animated them should be made galley slaves along with the writers. Most of the characters in the game are detestable from their ridiculous proportions and facial expressions alone. I think this might be a generational thing - modern 3D cartoons probably look a lot like this. But let's not beat around the bush. It's aggravatingly ugly and anyone who likes it has no taste. The atmosphere in the game is gone entirely to shit, and whatever sense of historical gravity earlier Civilization games might have held on to is clearly no longer there. Again, sure, it's just a game, but this is a poorer game for it.

Yeah, the writing and visual style alone are enough to sink this ship. The gameplay fails to keep it afloat. 
City-states aren't just single-city civs but a completely separate type of entity. So now you have barbarians, civilizations and city-states, and each has completely different rules and mechanics. You even get quests. Quests! What is this, some shitty RPG? Why yes, yes it is! You even get to level up your city governors, who come in various distinct classes, and give them specialist skills! And the governors are fixed, pre-made fictional characters with names and identities that have nothing whatsoever to do with your civilization but are instead a diverse and colorful cast form around the world! What a joke.

Wonders still work on the basis of winner-takes-it-all, and no matter how much of a genre and series staple this is, I never liked it and never will.

Unit movement is a chore. Unit automation isn't up to the job.

City districts can never be removed, replaced or repositioned, so you'd better know from turn 1 where you plan to place each district, wonder and whatnot. And I'm not being hyperbolic here, the top most-downloaded mods for this game are city planning aides.

The World Congress is overcomplicated without actually doing much.

There are too many game mechanics, and all of them are too shallow.

The UX is often cumbersome, displays too little relevant information, requires too many clicks to get things done, and has inconsistent keyboard shortcuts. The UI is very uninspired and makes very inefficient use of screen real estate.

The music runs the gamut from inappropriately grandiose to boring to annoying. The soundscape is probably the least impressive in any Civ game I played so far.

Combat animations are often nonsensical.

Tooltips are often absent where I'd have wanted them, and the ones that are there offer very limited information.

The narrator seems strangely angry much of the time.

The pacing is off; you rush through the tech tree with barely enough time to build one of half the things it unlocks. I guess this is another step taken to make the game more accessible, firstly by shortening overall campaign length and secondly by drowning people in a sense of progress without actually forcing them to get their hands dirty by actively doing something with it.

One new thing I like is that you can get a leg up on some technologies by performing specific actions related to them. That's somewhat intuitive and fun. So far that's also the only thing I think Civ6 has actually done to improve on the formula.

Really not what I was looking for in a game of Civilization. Yeah I know some of my criticism applies to older entries in the series as well, but that doesn't do this one any favors. Did you know that Civ6 is also shipped on mobile phones? I wasn't joking up there. That's probably one source of many of its problems.

Overall I'd just rather play Civ4, maybe with a good mod, or some other 4X game altogether.

147273155.review:
Not bad. It's not necessarily an improvement over civ 5, it is different than civ 5 and does some things better, some things worse.

Here are some of the main new mechanics and my opinion on them:

Districts: You place these on tiles and they make up most of the buildings you can make in a city. There are two main consequences of this new system. One, it requires significantly more time and effort to play the game in an optimal way since which tiles you place your districts on is very important. While I like this in single player, it makes multiplayer more tedious. Two, it kills "tall" builds in a pretty extreme manner. While some people complained civ 5 took its pro-tall approach a bit far, the districts system completely kills tall builds because districts simply have more yields than tiles and they are limited by the number of cities you have. It is also advantageous to place cities close enough to make their districts close to each other for adjacency bonuses. There is also no penalty to making more cities other than settlers getting more expensive as you build more settlers. So there is really only one way to play this game and it's spamming as many cities as possible as close as possible.

Civics: Culture is now like a second type of science. Your culture yields allow you to advance in your civics tree similar to how you use science yields to advance in the science tree. I like this mechanic. It adds more depth to the strategy without being boring or tedious. Civics can be just as important as techs depending on what you are going for so this makes low-science high-culture builds possible, even in multiplayer. You'll still want to catch up in science at some point but prioritizing culture over science is a valid strategy. Overall, pretty good mechanic.

Policies: These are kind of part of the new civics system but also a separate mechanic. Civics unlock policies and government types and you can run a certain number of policies based on your government type. This mechanic can feel a bit overwhelming and tedious at first but after a few hundred hours of play, I started liking this mechanic too. It is also something that adds strategic depth to the game.

Loyalty: This is essentially a mechanic they invented to stop extreme forward settling and I really like the idea, although there are some issues with implementation. The population of your cities emanate an aura of loyalty to your civilization and if you settle a city far away from your civilization and close to an enemy civilization who has a lot of high-pop cities nearby, that city will flip to the enemy civ. While this mostly works well, it can feel really dumb on congested starts on deity difficulty where your capital can start losing loyalty already in the very first few turns. They probably should have made the capital have higher defensive pressure or something along those lines.

Other than the new mechanics, compared to civ 5, I think the new art style is significantly worse and in addition, they seem to have followed "diversity" quotas when choosing the leaders. There are some female leaders who weren't of any real historical relevance.

The soundtrack is great. It might even be better than the civ 5 soundtrack.

Overall, it's a decent game which has some advantages and disadvantages compared to civ 5. It's probably worth a try, especially on sale.

Overall Score: 7/10

A single luxury resource gives 4 amenities that get divided up among your cities with the amenities going to whichever city needs it most. Multiple copes of a luxury resource don't normally give any more amenities and should be traded away.
Gold is highly useful, make sure to not neglect Harbors/Commercial Districts too much early on as they're the primary method of acquiring new Trade Routes for bringing in wealth and growing your new cities.
Plan ahead with your district positions by checking the adjacency bonuses they get. A common example is placing a Campus and/or Holy Site on a tile surrounded by mountains, or a Harbor near coastal resources. Adjacencies also work between different cities, for example districts from two different cities can get a bonus from each other.
Certain district buildings, primarily those from the Industrial and Entertainment districts, also provide (by default) a non-stacking bonus to cities within a 6-tile radius which can make those districts more useful when placed near multiple cities than in the outskirts.
Don't forget about the ability to harvest features such as forests and bonus resources with Builders. For example plonking a district on a forest tile simply removes the forest without yielding anything, so it's always preferable to first use a Builder to remove the forest for the big one-time boost and then start district construction there.

I got this for the June 2021 Humble Bundle Choice and I am SO glad I didn't spend the full $60 price tag for it . I even remember going "Civ 6? Yuck. I guess I can just install it when I'm bored and see what it's like compared to Civilization V".

Well, I installed it 3 days ago to see how that idea would go and I just uninstalled it yesterday - never playing this again.

I definitely agree with most of the reviewers that Civilization 5 is far superior than this version of Civilization 6. I just don't understand how a company like Fireaxis could get so many things wrong WHEN THEY HAVE PRIOR GAMES AND SEQUELS TO REFERENCE!

Now to the nitty gritty - Here's a list of my frustrations:

[list]
    [*] I love the new characters - can't stand the artwork style choice - I understand trying to make it more of a cartoon to reach a wider audience - but now it's just like "Clash of Clans" or "Boom Beach" - the artwork actually hurts my eyes with how utterly shit it looks -_-

    [*] Give us a way to disable the World Congress (without editing files or grabbing mods) - it was much more manageable in Civ 5 and actually made sense - the way it is used in this iteration seems like it's to camouflage the lack of content or lack of new ideas from Civ 5. It's even more apparent with the fact the World Congress gets called almost every other screen frame update...

           [*] Additionally, the World Congress used to ONLY be started by a player/bot that initiates it (from what I understand in Civ 5) AND it reveals all the other players/empires in the game. This version just spontaneously starts right after meeting 1 civilization and everyone is wearing a cloak over their heads - definitely engaging...

    [*] The repetitive random dialog interactions from bot players is beyond obnoxious - it's almost as frequent as World Congress votes. I move one unit, bot brings me to a splash screen to interrupt what I'm doing - okay, cool, exit from the dialog and continue on. not even 2 minutes later, the same bot (or a new bot) engages with the same dialog from 2 minutes ago - okay, that's a bit annoying, but it's not a big deal, let's move on. Then it happens a third time, a fourth time, and then a fifth time - I'm not even talking the initial engagement dialogs when you FIRST meet a new civilization - Civilization 5 wasn't THAT obnoxious - this game though, this is just lazy developers riding the brand name and flaunting their shit artwork design.

    [*] The lack of automated workers and how they have "limited improvement uses" - this one bothered the hell out of me for a good portion of the short matches I played - my Civilization 5 strategy was to just train a worker, then send them off to do automated improvements and not worry about them (unless they were kidnapped by barbarians or another civilization). I can't really tell what game balancing the developers were attempting to achieve by not making them automated and giving them limited uses. Like, did a developer from Civilization 6 look at Civilization 5 and go "we need to change AT LEAST one mechanic to make this Civilization game more unique. But what exactly do we change? AHA we'll make the workers manual AND give them limited uses. INGENIOUS". I don't know, I'm just lobbing as much shit at this game for how bad it is.

    [*] Governors are just an awful mechanic, they don't really do much of anything - what's the point of them?
[/list]

And here's a short list of the somewhat "good" ideas:

[list]
    [*] Biome/region specific wonders - pretty cool concept - requires the player actually start a city on a spot to be allowed to build the wonder - the old way was still funnier when America could just randomly build the Pyramid of Giza or the Eiffel Tower. Replacing one of your tiles with the wonder is still 50-50 with me.

    [*] Government types are pretty cool - planning out your political research (purple bar) along with the technology research (blue bar) again just feels like "we need to differentiate this sequel from Civilization 5".
[/list]

Yeah, that's pretty much it. Glad I only spent about 7 hours playing it before realizing how much of a flaming shit heap this game is. Maybe Civilization 7 will be better...

Sid Meier's Civilization VI is a true gem in the strategy game genre, offering an immersive and addictive experience that will keep you hooked for countless hours. With its deep gameplay mechanics, expansive scope, and engaging historical theme, it stands as the epitome of strategic empire building.

One of the greatest strengths of Civilization VI lies in its depth and complexity. From the very beginning, you're tasked with guiding a fledgling civilization through the ages, making crucial decisions on technology, culture, diplomacy, and warfare. The game's mechanics are intuitive and robust, offering a wealth of strategic options that allow you to shape your civilization's destiny.

The attention to detail in Civilization VI is commendable. Each leader and civilization is intricately designed, with unique abilities, units, and bonuses that reflect their historical characteristics. The game's art style is vibrant and visually appealing, bringing the world to life with its colorful landscapes and well-crafted animations.

The diplomacy system in Civilization VI adds another layer of depth to the gameplay. Negotiating with other leaders, forming alliances, and navigating through geopolitical challenges requires careful consideration and decision-making. The introduction of agendas and hidden agendas for each leader makes diplomacy even more dynamic and unpredictable, adding a layer of intrigue to your interactions.

Civilization VI also excels in its replayability. With multiple victory conditions, different leaders to play as, and a wide range of strategies to employ, each playthrough offers a unique experience. The inclusion of expansions and DLCs further enhances the game, introducing new civilizations, mechanics, and scenarios that expand the game's longevity.

The multiplayer mode in Civilization VI is also a standout feature. Whether competing or cooperating with friends, engaging in epic battles or negotiating alliances, the multiplayer experience is robust and allows for engaging and strategic gameplay sessions.

However, it's worth noting that the game has a relatively steep learning curve. Newcomers to the series might feel overwhelmed by the complexity of mechanics and systems at first. However, the tutorial and in-game tooltips do an excellent job of guiding players, and the learning process ultimately adds to the rewarding experience of mastering the game.

In conclusion, Sid Meier's Civilization VI is a strategic masterpiece that offers endless hours of captivating gameplay. Its depth, attention to detail, and immersive historical theme make it a must-play for fans of the genre. With its robust mechanics, engaging diplomacy, and exceptional replayability, Civilization VI stands as one of the finest strategy games available on Steam.

Sid Meier's Civilization VI is a game that will take you on an epic journey through time and history. As the leader of a civilization, you will be tasked with building your empire from the ground up, exploring new territories, and interacting with other civilizations on your way to greatness.

The first thing that stands out about Civilization VI is its stunning graphics and design. The game is beautifully rendered, with a level of detail that makes each civilization and its unique traits come to life. From the lush forests of Brazil to the arid deserts of Egypt, every landscape is crafted with care, allowing you to fully immerse yourself in the world of Civilization VI.

But the beauty of Civilization VI isn't just skin deep. The game boasts an incredible depth of gameplay that will keep you engaged for hours on end. Each decision you make as a leader has real consequences, and the game's AI is intelligent enough to keep you on your toes. From diplomacy to military strategy, from culture to science, there are so many paths to victory in Civilization VI that you'll never run out of things to do.

One of the standout features of Civilization VI is its "district" system, which allows you to specialize your cities in different areas of expertise. Want to focus on science? Build a campus district. Interested in culture? Construct a theater district. This system adds a level of customization to your cities that was missing in previous Civilization games, and it's incredibly satisfying to see your empire grow and evolve as you build new districts and structures.

Overall, Sid Meier's Civilization VI is a game that will appeal to anyone who loves strategy, history, and exploration. It's a beautifully crafted game that offers endless hours of engaging gameplay, and it's sure to become a favorite among fans of the series and newcomers alike. If you're looking for a game that will challenge you and keep you engaged for weeks or even months, look no further than Civilization VI.

132253933.review:
So I came here from Civilization V(which, by far, the very best purchase I've ever made on this distribution platform), and what I can tell you, potential buyers is Sid Meier's Civilization VI doesn't disappoint. 

The learning curve is deep but gentle. You'll lose a few games in the beginning, but after a while, you'll find your own way of making the game work in your favor. In fact, Civilization VI is one of the few games that when you lose, you respect it. This game is profound in strategy, tactics, and other fancy military philosophy terms.
You can build all sorts of World Wonders. You learn how to strategically zone your city so you can build your wealth and prosperity and defend it from foreign aggressors. You can play dirty with spies and all sorts of political shenanigans. You can go to war, betray your friends, or you can make other players regret going to war with you, and help your friends keep up with the advancements of the game. You can explore the map, make fun of the United Nations, fight Barbarians(or turn them into your people). Ultimately, your task is to build a civilization that stands the test of time. Also, you can look at your hard-earned empire on screen and exhale. Such great feelings.


What I love about Civ VI is that it made military combat much more accessible for me. Age of Empires is always too fast, Total War is always too awkward with camera angles, Europa Universalis IV is always "too many things happen at once", and Civilization's turn-based combat is perfect. Not that is easier, but a tad more accessible. Plus it looks quite corny on screen.

Civilization VI got a very good PS4 - esque visual. This means you don't need a super expensive machine to play it, and it still looks good regardless of the graphical advancement race out there. However, Civilization VI does suffer from other lags, stuttering, and bugs on a multiplayer scale with more than 4 players.

The soundtrack and music collection in this game is sublime! You can throw any fancy compliments at it and it's still not enough. From modernized folk music to classical songs made atomic, each session of the game surely made you a more worldly person, in terms of audio taste.

The price is neither cheap nor expensive. I think it's just right. You should buy it in sale and be happy.

If you're familiar with Civilization V, then Civilization VI is actually a great return to the original Civilization philosophy(Civ V was great, but also a bit outlandish). Both games are great, and that's the reason why Civlization VI should be in your library.

To new Civilization players(or IV and III players), it's great. It's everything you ever dreamed of a board game can be: entertaining and profound at the same time. It's addictive, comical, and ultimately, a good game.

One more turn, Señor!

134155603.review:
Civilization VI is, mostly, a pretty direct improvement on V, making a variety styles of play and victories to achieve fun from get-go. It also adds extra complexity to things which is a mixed bag.

For those who don't know, Civilization is a series where you take some real world civilization like Egyptians, English or Chinese, and go trough from ancient to near future times while building cities, massive world wonders, and units that fight wars. Civilization V saw some numerous changes that pushed the game into allowing more varied victories, using hexagons instead of square tiles, and embracing subtly more boardgamey approach to mechanics. Here these mechancis get expanded on with some complexities, some hard to grasp, others apparently but involved, others much needed.

For once, the cities, staples of the series that previously always took up one tile on map, now spread out further over the world, with special districts like industrial or academic whose function is clear, and there is a lot of interactions between world and these districts now, like banding them together gives you bonuses, but also placing certain ones by environmental details will also provide bonus, like trade hubs by rivers or science districts by mountains or jungles. The world wonders are also placed on their own tile now, which means spamming wonders in single city is less viable now, plus you may need to sacrifice something else for that wonder sometimes - and also you need some real specific conditions sometimes - like snow, mountain or desert tiles. It feels a bit borrowed from Endless Legend city districts but it's also a major improvement.

The major focus of this version was to, unlike CivV, make all victory paths fun and deep from get go. It's not just warfare that has some tactical options, now religious and other units have upgrades and varied effects too, culture features artworks and historic artifacts you collect in varied ways, things like trade are integrated so you could harness them to spread religion. Ultimately it still boils down to having developed cities but so does warfare, so why not? Another cool bit that got built up on are city states, now there's a system where you expand a special "envoy" resource to get their bonuses, and if you are most invested, their support and special bonus. There's some interesting choices now, whether you want more smaller bonuses from most city states, or focus on several, or go all in building wonders and securing other means to improve your soft power.

One problem I can totally identify with this game is that it still can stretch out needlessly as with previous games, say tourism victory with several developed nations may get lengthy, but also there's some fiddly unit management trying to drag them around a continent still there, but also now some mechanics like beauty really lack in indication or clarity without hitting the wiki. These small nuances which actually matter a lot, and yet you don't get proper clarity ingame. Another thing is art style, it has some nice bits, some meh bits like how leaders range from cool to mobile game mascots (Please Civ, embrace some art style other than cartoony caricatures for your leaders already), but also while there was some intention of making it clear it just nontheless feels super noisy as you build up your cities or have a lot going on, takes time to grok the going ones.

Overall it's a legit worthwhile game, if you like more ambitious strategy games, 4X or grand strategy in particular, really consider getting this a try, the full package goes on sale for a good price.

There are three main reasons I am not recommending this game.

First off, it will run absolutely fine, then randomly decide not to work any more.  I go to load a game and it throws an exception and will not play any more.  I have searched for solutions and the only thing that works is uninstalling/reinstalling - then the existing saves load fine again.

Secondly, there are better games in the Civilisation Series.

And Third, key features in this one are simply broken.

It is a shame because I was looking forward to playing Civ6, and will probably still waste countless hours on it.  I did intend to buy on release.  Then I decided as an expensive game, I'd wait for the DLC's to be released - I have been burned before where it's ended up cheaper to just buy the whole thing again than it is to add the DLC later...  One thing led to another and I didn't end up buying until a recent sale.  Sadly despite many years, the kinks haven't been worked out.  Bright flashy animations do not make a Civlisation Game for me.  Gameplay is key and if that is good, it could be pixel art and would still be enjoyable.  Too many aspects of the Gameplay don't work.

My first play through had a very poor start.  Caught up with barbarians around my first city and by the time I really got going, I lacked room to expand due to more advanced nations nearby.  Frederick Barbosa decides to declare a surprise war and I realise I'm stuffed - there's simply no way my archers can stand up to his advanced cavalry units.  This is when I find out the AI can't do war...  He brings his TWO cavalry units to my capital and moves them around in circles waiting for me to bring them down with my city walls.  They didn't even attack!  At a certain point he just parks one in range of two of my cities until they are dead.  After that, he just didn't do anything, he had no more units.  So I sat my archers outside his nearest city for something like 50 turns bringing it's health down before capturing it with a horseman - and he goes whinging to the world congress!

Now that's another system that is completely broken.  My next playthrough I'm placed too close to my nearest neighbour, I send my warriors down and capture his only city, wiping him out at the start.  I build up my civilisation and have friendly relations with my two nearest neighbours...  Right up until we hit the medieval era.  Suddenly they are not happy that I'm holding the capital city of a civilisation they'd likely never heard of - they gang up and declare war!

I find the World Congress to be a symptom of the game being too self-aware of the fact it is a simulated board game.  It just doesn't find the blend between board game mechanics and developing a civilisation in a single player computer game.  Everything just happens because that's what the game rules dictate and not due to any particular event.  Example - Lets have a vote for which player to give some Victory Points to or whether Settlers should cost more to build...  WHY?  What has happened for us to need to take this decision?  It's a mechanic that might add something if you're playing against other human players - then you can discuss between yourselves and try to convince the others to vote for something that will benefit you, but not when playing against the AI.

The rest will just be bullet points - and yes some of these are carried over from previous games!
- Multi-tile cities with districts - I like the city development, but find the cities taking too much space on the map, would like them spread out more - smaller hexes with borders reflecting area of influence and not just city boundaries.
- Land units can swim?!?  Please stop this.  It defeats the point of building ships when your settlers/explorers can just pull one out of their back pocket when they need to cross an ocean.
- District bonuses.  Would be better to show all the bonuses a tile can confer so you can best place your district.  Annoying having to keep going back to the build menu to select each district to ensure you don't build over a tile which gave a better bonus for something else.
- Better presentation of stats in general, especially when something is getting boosted by a wonder or a tech.  I shouldn't have to memorise how everything comes together in order to decide what to do.
- Diplomacy is annoying.  Constant meaningless messages from other civs take you away from the game for far too long.  Really annoying to have a full screen animation just to receive a one-line message.  Just give us the message pop-up form!
- Don't like cities having their own garrison.  Prefer having to build/manage defensive units.  Don't like how cities can bombard units just by having walls - if they added +1 range to garrisoned archers or something that'd be better!
- Would rather have events, eras, etc to be in the context of your civilisation - instead of the context of you playing a board game.  "Ancient Walls" were not ancient when they were first built.  If my Civilisation is still building Crossbowmen, then I should still be in the "Medieval Era" - not moving into the "Modern Era" in the year 1900 because of another civ I've never met.  

Overall feels like the game has been built and is better suited to a multiplayer experience - but I don't have the appetite for playing such a long winded game in multiplayer.  Most of the small issues are just annoyances, but it is game breaking when the AI players are unable to fight a war and I have to keep uninstalling to make the game continue to work!

124440700.review: I've been playing Civilization since my friend let me play Civilization 3 back in 04' and since then I've played thousands of hours of this franchise, most of that time with my father on his Steam account. Like nearly every iteration in the Civilization franchise, Civilization 6 has advanced the 4X turn-based strategy genre and I recommend it. Civilization 6 has the usual staples of the franchise; unique flavours tailor made for to each Civ and their leader, a diversity of victory conditions, semi-historical progression from the ancient era to the near-future, and city-centred production of buildings/units (including famed wonders), and military tactics. New to Civilization 6 is district placement (and its adjacency bonuses), which adds a long-term strategic decision into each city's production cycle. Furthermore, the game's aesthetic is updated (though arguably too pretty for someone who favours more realistic graphics) and it has continued to receive lots of content since its 2016 launch (though that is locked into paid DLC). Beyond that, there are other minor changes to this iteration, but it does not represent a fundamental departure from Civilization 5. For many, that is exactly what they are looking for. Enough new content was introduced at launch (and ongoing) to meet (if not exceed) their expectations. As the saying goes: "If it's not broke don't fix it." But though I recommend and enjoy Civilization 6, I believe that Firaxis Games should have been braver in innovating the 4X turn-based strategy genre.

138206774.review:
Apart from what you can read in everyone else's reviews, I want to bring up a positive and a negative for this game that are less often mentioned. 

The positive you won't hear that often is that Civilization games are some of the most intuitive 4x games out there. Thanks to the fact that the game will ask you what to do with each available resource (be it research, city production or a unit), means that it's very unlikely that you end up completely wasting a big portion of your strength because you didn't know about it, as it may happen in other 4x games. If you feel overwhelmed by the concept of managing this much, Civilization 6 is probably the most likely game to ease you in the genre.

A negative that you won't hear much about is that once you get to max difficulty, you will get a fair challenge (deity isn't that hard once you figure out all mechanics), but you will also get shoehorned into the same paths. It feels really bad that some aspects of the game become either completely out of reach (like building the great library is nearly impossible, if there's an AI that builds wonders it will build it before you can even research it) or a huge gamble to try (basically almost all wonders and any strategy that doesn't involve having 10 cities by the midgame). And then once you catch up to the most advanced AI, as long as it's not already a few turns away from victory, it's way too easy to win the game. I wish the devs added a machine learning based AI so we weren't limited in our early game tactics and we weren't bored by the late game when we already won. But that issue is only an issue because the game is so great and it feels like a lot of potential is wasted by the way it handles high difficulty.

129585423.review:
‘Just one more turn.’ I said, and suddenly it was 3h00 on a Monday morning. Or rather the story of how one turn turns into 100.

As this is my first delve into turn-based games, I was a bit skeptical of the format. Would it be fun enough to keep playing? Isn’t it too difficult to just start doing this without keeping track of every game mechanic? Oh, was my doubt misplaced …

Story
There is not much of a ‘single player story / campaign’ kind of thing. Every play-through (and it will be a lot) will be different, have different characters, different maps, different outcomes … I love the fact that certain leaders require certain types of play to get the most out of it. The narrator only adds to the ‘historical’ nature of the story you create yourself. No score however because it just doesn’t really apply. NA/10

Game-play
Where to start. As stated previously, this was my first encounter with such type of game. Having conquered my fears about mechanics, strategy, builds, information, … I really fell in love with CIV 6. Although on the outside these games seem very stationary and dull, it could not be much further from the truth. The changing environment, expanding countries, research advancements, exploration, … gave a dynamic kind of feel I didn’t expect to experience here. Props to the developers for creating this overall feeling. The cliche of ‘just one more turn’ is the perfect compliment to the achievements made when creating this beautiful game. On multiple occasion I found myself forgetting every sense of time and keep on playing, well into the night. Many of times have I regretted playing until 3h00 in the morning on workdays. Yet, every time I return and [i]keep doing the same thing over and over again, expecting a different outcome[/i] (See what I did there 😉?) If you are new to this genre, don’t be afraid to jump straight in. 8/10 

Music
The music in CIV 6 mostly consists of background music and a narrator’s voice. Both add to the overall feeling of discovery, historical milestones, grandeur, diplomatic developments, technological advancements, science, … At multiple times I found myself having a blast humming in sync with the background music and feeling like being inside the past. It could get a little bit repetitive at times, but that is normal considering my play-throughs consisted of 4 to 6h sessions in one single sitting. This doesn’t however take anything away from it. 8/10

Art-style / graphics
Although this is overall a beautiful game, it doesn’t have the most advanced graphics, and a specific cartoony art-style that could perhaps not be your thing. I found myself questioning this during the first 5 minutes of play, but quickly grew fond of the style and ‘don’t take yourself to seriously’-type of art this game displays. It is after all just that, a game. Could it have more fancy / up-to-date graphics? Yes. Could it have a less cartoony feeling and be more realistic? Maybe, probably. Would this impact the fun or feeling I have playing this game? No. CIV 6 has its own identity, and with that comes this art-style. 7/10

Oh Yeah
One thing I found both fun and annoying: The barbarians. In the early stages of a play-through they are quite strong and will obliterate everything on their path. Really annoying when you have a specific strategy in mind. After a little while however, they just become an annoyance, being there but not really mattering. I get why they are present, but man do they irritate me from time to time. 
Secondly, I found the religion aspect of the game to be dull and not worth my time. I don’t think the developers spent as much time on this mechanic as on others, as it feels a little bit tacked on. None of my play-throughs I won with it, and on only one occasion did I even bother including this. I understand that this is included in the game, even necessary, but I personally think a different kind of meta-game is needed to make this an attractive aspect. 

Aftermath
As of writing this review, I have completed and won 5 play-throughs on random maps with random leaders on random difficulties. I find the difficulty maybe a bit too easy, as I have won all of them, but it is still a challenge and still satisfying to win. All my time however was spent in single player mode. In next play-throughs, I will involve some friends and tackle multiplayer, having no Idea how this works. I will also look to create some custom games to increase overall difficulty or change the settings. Or set myself some goals.

To summarize
+ Game-play, very addictive
+ Story, very compelling although you must create it yourself
+ music, Immersive background
- Religion, bland and not attractive

Overall score 7.5/10

I highly recommend getting this game. You will get addicted to keep playing a turn and when all is said and done, the satisfaction is there. Will probably come back to this for the next 5 years or until a new one comes out (Yes, I’m into Turn-based now).

142038275.review:
Civ6 had a lot to live up to, and honestly, I can see why it may not be everyone's cup of tea.

I was a pretty avid Civ5 player. I enjoy turn-based simulation games, and I spent a lot of time just enjoying the solo-player experience with Civ5. I found the game's AI to be competitive at even the Warlord and Prince levels, for the filthy casual I am. 

That being said, I don't feel the same urgency or tactics in Civ6. The AI felt extremely dull, even in a domination-only mode with war declared multiple times. I seemed to be the only one who realized that we were at war. Civ5 AI would have hordes of combat units flooding your borders at any time. Meanwhile, Civ6, I just walked right in and started taking city after city (be it, it is a bit obnoxious how long it takes to bring one down from full health.) Combat rarely took place between the other AI. I had to quite literally force combat. Barbarians weren't even that big of a problem, except for when they have the chance to convert to a city-state. That's really annoying when its smack dab in the middle of what I wanted to be my expansion. Furthermore their tile usage was awful. The AI also wouldn't build anything or upgrade their land. I would be turn 400/500 in and they wouldn't have made barely any city improvements by the time I took over. Like, am I not remembering Civ5 right, and thinking the AI was far more complex, or am I just that bad? I nuked a few cities, just for the funsies, and came back to the area with an army about 40/50 turns later and they didn't repair anything (tiles on fire, etc), and the cities were still sacked at zero health??

I also don't know if its a bug, but one of the AI kept nuking the same city over and over and over again, despite it basically being nothing by nuke 3. Kept happening for about six or seven turns, with two nukes each turn, before I finally walked up to the city and took it over with a single unit. 

Some of the system changes I also don't really like. The trade route system for one requires constant care and selection. Rather than the old model of build a road, you're good because it assumes people will use it to trade as a built in function, Civ6 requires you to actively manage trade routes with Trade Units. It's tedious and you don't get consistent bonuses with the trade. The Trade Unit also builds roads which are nice, but the roads don't establish a route by default. It adds a system I don't find too enjoyable, unless you're into the 'manage everything you can', in which case you will find yourself satisfied. Like at my end-game, I could have like nearly thirty trade routes... Who wants to manage THIRTY units just for trade? 

You also can't trade captured capital cities for some reason? I just wanted to pillage and loot and trade off cities cause I didn't want to manage more, yet, if you don't want a capital, you have to select Raze or you're stuck with it forever. That's really stupid. 

I also don't really like the change to where builders have limited use. Again, I appreciated the ability to be 'hands off' when it came to tile maintenance. I would just set my city stats and citizens to what I wanted accomplished, made a few builders, then let them auto-set tiles for me. Civ6 completely removes this, and instead requires players to manage tile building, and you only get a handful of uses before you must spawn a new builder to continue work. I found this, again, too micromanaged for me.

I do find the city management systems a bit better, tho. I enjoy districting and managing buildings, as well as the use-case for each type of district you build and what it means for your cities. I also like how you can hire barbarians to do stuff or ignore you. I also appreciate how spawning units will differ based on the type of unit it is and what kind of districts you have, meaning you can potentially spawn more stuff on one city. 

The new art style I don't mind. Honestly, its not so much that any of it bothered me, except, I hate the new fog of war style. I'd rather it just be a darkened map color rather than converting to a 'paper map' texture. It throws me off, and I just don't like the map's inconsistent look. 

That being said, after ~600 turns, I don't find myself wanting just one more...

Let me begin by explaining my "No" answer to the question "Would you recommend this game...":
What I literally mean by this, is that I will not urge others to get this "because it's so awesome,.." etc.
It is a good game. It is a polished, virtually bug-free game. No complaints. And "if you liked Civilization, this is something similar."

My misgivings come from the game being Civilization VI. Because this is not the next Civ game, after Civ V, that I wanted.

I've taken my time, played 92 hours, before accepting this conclusion. It's not the disaster that I considered Civ IV was. But it's also not the improved, developed from Civ V, game that I wanted. Instead it's yet another new game. Just as if it was another civ-like game, released to compete with civilization. New ideas, new mechanics. And unfortunately, I don't think any, single one of the many changes to gameplay is really an improvement. On the contrary. It is different though. But why would it be fun? A "refreshing change"?
Now, Civ V could have some problems with synching progress to pace, particularly on faster pace and smaller maps, making it feel weird, But that's nothing compared to Civ VI. IMO, part of the weirdness and unsynch comes from all the time cities must spend to make builders or districts, neither activity furthering your city or civilization.
The maps turn out more boring than in Civ V. I don't think they are smaller, haven't checked though, but they feel smaller, more cramped. The assortment of leaders is uninspiring, to say the least. The cartoonish graphics don't appeal to me either. Gameplay feels more static than in Civ V. There's more going on but less happening, is how I'm tempted to describe it. But maybe I'm just playing it wrong. Can't be sure.
The really big changes feel ideologically motivated and are more an annoyance than a positive addition.

I'm not completely done with this game, but I'm sure I'll keep playing Civ V more, much more.
Pity, there were so many incremental improvements that could have been done to Civ V.

125064177.review:
I've played many Civ games over the years and will probably continue playing Civ games, but overall I would not recommend Civ 6 to most people.

There are a lot of really questionable/bad quality of life decisions the dev team made on this game.
- An admiral will only ever have 5 movement, yet many ships can get 8 or 9 movement. Because of this, linking an admiral becomes a nerf to your naval units. This is one of many oversights with an incredibly easy fix--just merge the admiral to the unit, or at least set the admiral's movement speed to its escort's speed.
- Computer civs don't have enough divergence. The World Congress is the strongest example of this; they all vote exactly the same way, meaning A) their voting is incredibly predictable and B) there's no point in voting any way except how they do, because even if you stock up your diplomacy points for the ENTIRE GAME, you will literally never outvote them.
- On that note, no amount of befriending has been enough to convince a computer to support you to the top. In my opinion, this is a change for the worse from civ 5 where you could convince computer civs to vote for you as world leader and act like an actual ally throughout the game.
- It's too easy for districts to be pillaged for how long it takes to repair them. If an enemy spy triggers insurgents from your neighborhood (which they will because, again, literally every computer civ targets ONLY you with spy operations), your neighborhood will be instantly pillaged AND units will be spawned that will suicidally pillage nearby districts instead of fighting your units. You'll then have to spend 6+ turns, on Standard speed, repairing *each* district. Once you add in natural disasters, much of your late game production can become entirely devoted to repairing districts or else just leaving them pillaged. This is not fun gameplay.
- Microtransactions. Not much else to say here, but I don't approve of this game's tactic of "Hey, we made Canada a civilization. Want Canada? Pay us $3." Extra civs should be lumped into expansions with real, substantial content changes.

There's still a lot to enjoy here. They made some game modes and some mechanics that absolutely throw balance out the window and result in tiles with 20+ yields, which can result in some pretty fun chaos. It's also still got most of the usual good Civ stuff with the many different victory options and civilizations to try to master.

I just feel like they went backwards in a lot of ways from Civ 5 and I wish they would put some effort into polishing at least the more glaring quality of life issues in the game.

Another times, when I just look at it, it feels unnecessary. I would settle it as a good one. Not sure. If we have round world horizontally

tl;dr: Just play Civ V instead.

Well, I've been trying to love this game for 642 hours now (as opposed to 3532 hours wasted/enjoyed in Civ V). Some observations about this game as it stands alone, now that the adjustment period from Civ V is out of the way:

 - AI's military tactics are still extremely weak. It does not assemble its units for advantage, attack when it has the advantage, or defend its cities effectively. You'd think a fundamental goal for any game like this would be to have fronts naturally develop, as in a real-life war. Nope. Scattered, random skirmishes that the AI always loses. You can run the map with 1-2 infantry or cavalry units, plus 1 artillery.
 - Diplomacy mechanics bring nothing to the game. If you so much as defend yourself or retaliate against an aggressor, as one does in war, you're branded a warmonger. Were the Allies warmongers in WWII for conquering Germany? Leaders relentlessly spam you with their disapproval, consuming ridiculous numbers of UI-animation seconds before you can esc/cancel with each one. Despite claims that leaders approve of certain things, it seems to be an either/or, all-or-nothing, hair-trigger mechanism. A leader will love you one turn and denounce you the next, because they expected you to have one more military unit that turn or something. There is no nuance, spectrum, or "scoring" to this system, as far as I can tell, contrary to the claim that there are several levels between "friendly" and "denounced." It's a waste of effort to try to get along with everyone while trying to win a science or cultural victory. Just let them inevitably declare war and fight them off.
 - Firaxis has figured out how to make leader interactions annoy you further and waste even more of your time. Clearly, you want to be spammed with an inconsequential 30-second message for "good job" "or "I hate you" several times each turn - often interrupting your next click - and wait an additional several seconds for it to respond to multiple Esc presses.
 - The AI engine is SLOW. I've played on an i7-5930k and an i7-6850k, and on both, it takes up to a minute to process AI turns in late game. I think most hours spent playing this game are for the "please wait" stage. Why Firaxis cannot take advantage of parallel processing, or cache possible scenarios in advance while you're taking your turn, I do not know. There should at least be an option (or default) where other player moves have faster animations so that you can see what's happening without losing time, without making all the animations bizarrely short like in quick combat.
 - The lack of automated builders brings more tedium to the game than it does craftsmanship. In late game, I really no longer care about the details of each city; there are no real mistakes to be made, and I do not want to micromanage every single tile of every single city on a standard to huge map. Keeping the charge mechanic on builders, but adding an option to automate (or making it a technology, like a "self-reliance" civic) would probably still encourage early game caretaking, while removing late game tedium.
 - The game in general just feels slow and tedious. This is in no small part due to terrain penalties and weak road bonuses for unit movement. (And the fact you essentially can't deliberately construct roads; military engineer roads are too expensive.) Even in the middle ages, no, it didn't take 20 years for a unit to cross a civilization. It takes a lot of the oomph and fun out of army mobilization when it's far more practical to move single powerful units against the weak AI than to assemble melee and archer units into a tactically appropriate formation. There's simply no reason to bother with a combined arms / blitzkrieg approach in this game.
 - I like the districts mechanic in principle, but it's not flexible enough. Districts should be removable at a cost, or at the VERY least, there should be more information displayed in early game about the future optimal options for each tile. It's really not fun to try to wing it and guess where it will be best to place an industrial, commercial, or theater district in the future, before you can select those districts to see the adjacency bonuses. (Or for placing future wonders, each of which have strict, arbitrary requirements.) At the very least, there should be some sort of filter (a lens?) to display all adjacency bonuses on a tile.
 - Tile info popovers are slow and unreliable. Just show the dang info when I mouse over. I'm not afraid. At least make it so that mousing over a resource icon by accident doesn't prevent tile info from displaying until I leave the tile and reenter.
 - Personally, I think the air unit mechanics in this game feel awkward and unnatural. Why not just emulate real life instead? Carriers in real life can project power farther and to more places at once than allowed by the 2 short-range aircraft, as can air bases. Jet fighters intercept attacks, like in Civ V. They don't sit there and take it. No cruise missiles or ballistic conventional weapons in this game? They do exist in real life... Also, by the time you can build aerodromes and project significant air power, you could far more easily have created 3 times as many land units of greater power. The air game seems to be rather pointless, and is placed too late in the game in terms of military advancement. Air units are too weak for the time they take to acquire. Minor note: you'd also think cheap surveillance or attack drones would be making an appearance by now.
 - Nuclear weapons are thankfully a little more realistic in this game, since they really ruin whatever land you'd like to conquer, but at the same time, you've got to ask, of what use are they in the game? The AI never has a powerful enough conventional army where you'd need nukes to defend yourself. Since you can conquer all other civs with 3 army units, it's foolish to nuke them first and ruin your takings. Best guess, if you're trying to win a science or cultural victory, you'd like to ruin everyone else's day? If you're in the mood to go for one of those victories, initiating nuclear war doesn't really fit the bill.
 - In my experience, all games devolve into domination matches. As soon as someone attacks you (inevitable), you will have an army and be branded a warmonger for defending yourself. So you might as well remove the nuisance of neighboring civs who like to attack you. Nature then takes its course. Maybe this is a bit realistic, but it doesn't exactly meet the 4x, varied experience Firaxis is trying to accomplish.
 - City state and liberation mechanics are flawed. There is no real way to defend an allied city state, or even just to play peacekeeper. You're not notified that they are attacked, and you are not given any casus belli for declaring war. War of liberation (after the fact) also doesn't seem to become available when it should. If you do liberate a city, all your units are immediately expelled from that territory, bizarrely and unnaturally disrupting your advance in a way that just wouldn't happen in real life. Takes the fun out of liberating that neighboring continent that had been conquered by a single civ; liberating France as in WWII is literally impossible.
 - So tired of hearing "best not to aid that city state" from other leaders. What are you talking about? I didn't aid any city state. Which one???
 - The tech/civic boost mechanic is neat, but it makes games far too uneven. Either I hit all the boosts by the luck of the map and launch a moon landing or accidentally win a culture victory in 1700, or I'm tied up in a war for 500 years (in which I can't go on the offensive to end it or else become a warmonger), miss a lot of the boosts, and discover petroleum in 1960.

I fired up this game this morning on a sick day to pass the time, and found that it's more fun to write this review than to sit through any more hours with the game. That should tell you something.

After putting in about 1500 hours at the time of writing this, I think it's safe to say I can write a somehwat informed review (because I have opinions and I like to share them, that's why). I'm no veteran Civ player, I've only played 5 and 6, though I'm aware that 3 and 4 are still good games. However, even coming from 5 which had it's own disappointing launch, 6 is a massive drop in depth and quality. No matter how hard I try, I cannot lose myself in this game the way I did in 5. I'm never on edge, wondering what will happen next, because I know what'll happen next. War. War for settling wrong. War for being the wrong religion. War for governing wrong. War for being too strong and too week (at the same time). War for not trading. War for simply existing in a manner that doesn't quite suit somebody else. What seems to be an attempt to inject some personality to diplomacy with "agendas", results in predictable games where everyone hates you, or everyone loves you (until they don't). There's never a middle ground.

On agendas, certain civs simply don't play themselves as they should. Hey Brazil, I see you've denounced literally everyone on Earth for making more great people than you. Would you like to change that? Maybe build a campus or theater square? No? Just gonna build another encampment? Thought so. Nice to meet you China. No I didn't realize you were the preemminent builder of wonders in the world. Do you know why? It's because you never built one China, that's why. Ah, Cleopatra, I see you're now chronically indecisive, as you simultaneously hate and love large militaries, and simply can't make your mind up. These agendas will override everything else you do with/to another civ. If you are friends with America and watch helpless as the Aztecs burn and pillage their way across the continent, you might be inclined to pitch in on good ol' America's behalf. But more fool you, because you see, America hates people who declare war on his neighbours, even if those neighbours are currently enslaving his own people and turning his cities to ash. A man's got to have a code after all. Now you're a warmonger. Why? Good question, but it's ok, Alexander the Great still loves you.

The next part of my rant jamboree is the design of the game, such as unit scaling and modelling and such. Before the game was launched there were many people who expressed concern over a "mobile game" aesthetic, justly concerned that 2K might be trying to grant their next installment with some more mass appeal at the expense of anyone being able to take this seriously. Thankfully, the gameplay hasn't been dumbed down, so much as screwed up (see agendas). I am not terrified of this army of strangely proportioned stretch armstrong figures marching towards me, because I'm too distracted by the trader, whose cart is 2 or 3 times taller than my palace. In Civ 5, when the Mongol horde was at my borders, it stretched on and on like, well, a horde. Now it appears to be maybe 20 horses all together, each being roughly the size of an entire building, and altogether looking rather silly. If course there's another reason not to be intimidated by the Mongol horde, or anyone else's horde for that matter. The entire combined forces of all other AI civs could be beaten back with a damp rag and a can do attitude.

The AI in Civ 6 cannot war, which is particularly damning in a game that always ends in a war. Alexander the Great of Macedon may command the most fearsome force known to man, but rest assured, it'll be soundly defeated by simply doing the following; ranged units + garrion promotion, place in city centres and encampments. Or just wait them out, when you think the enemy has gained the advantage they'll just sit there and contemplate life, or throw themselves away on fortified units with ranged support. It's worth pointing out that at launch the AI did not even know how to use boats or planes, so I wouldn't hold your breath or anyone elses for any of this to change any time soon.

I will now try to think of some nice things to say about Civ 6. You can use mods in multiplayer games fairly easily. See that overpowered civ from your favorite TV show that was obviously made by a fan with no thought to game balance? Yup, you can bring that into a game with your friends and make them regret basking in your presence. The most fun I've managed to have in this game has been with friends, where the only real competition in science, culture, faith and of course, war, are the other human players. The AI might aswell be so many other city states. Oh and the music. While I miss wartime music (listening to the cheerful Kongo theme while nuclear hellfire engulfs the planet is a bit jarring) the whole idea of music evolving with eras is just fantastic. Entering the industrial era to "Scotland the Brave" blaring in your ears while you agressively bagpipe the inferior nations of the world into submission is satisfying, to say the least. But then you realize that you're building the same cities all over the map, and that the last game you tried to get into was the same as this one, and that enemy you've been contending with isn't really contending so much as falling behind because he decided to give up on winning. And then everyone denounces you for being close to winning yourself. And then I get tired of this and try and get Civ 5 to work again with a bagillion mods.

(oh yeah and districts aren't that special, I always end up building the same 2 or 3 different cities with no variation)

(I'll stop typing now I am very tired)

EDIT:

I have so many hours played in this game because of friends who used to enjoy playing it. As they lost interest, I lost interest. There were other mods I used that also made it fun, which are no longer usable since the summer patch (I think, it might have been the spring one I can't remember). I cannot reccomend this game because it does not stand up on it's own as a civ game should. Time and time again the modding community has found and fixed bugs that should have been dealt with before release. Maybe the next big dlc will make Civ6 a game worthy of the franchise, I don't know. Until such a time I do not think anyone should buy this game. That is my opinion and I am entitled to it no matter how many hours I have played, or whether or not I "got my money's worth".

(While I understand where some people are coming from with the "you played a bunch but didn't like it so why did you play it" mentality, I would not take any review seriously with few hours played, regardless of wether they reccomended it or not. If my friends came with the game in a sort of package deal, then sure I'd reccomend it, but I got them elsewhere)

GS EDIT:

Another DLC, and with it some more game mechanics for the AI to struggle with. There's really not much more to it than that. Obvious one is climate change and disasters, of which there is very little change and it's not very disastrous. Just keep a builder or two on stand by if you're in a disaster prone area and you'll be fine. Of the couple times I've had the patience to see a game to completion, not once did the sea level rise, which leads me to believe that you have to really go out of your way to screw up the planet. The main incentive for burning fossil fuels seems to be powering tier 3 buildings in certain districts. Not only is this not necessary, as these buildings still provide their standard yield, but you can just hold out for cleaner energy sources a couple more techs down the line.

The other "new" mechanic is the world congress (for some reason starting in the year 500 AD), which at the very least is a more nostalgic kind of stupid. Fans of Civ 5 can look back on fond memories of the great nations of the world banding together against the true enemy of civilization, truffles. Voting yourself is pointless (unless you're playing Sweden), because the AI will mass vote to ban random things regardless of whether it hurts them or not.
